title: Friday, 9th September, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Hi there

PM

We start abroad.

PM

Far side of America

11:01 am
PM

With this chap

PM

PM

John Stumpf

11:01 am
PM

Chairman of Wells Fargo and Company

PM

For six years now

PM

Also president from 2005 through to last year

11:02 am
PM

How he is still in his job I have no idea

PM

And why this story is not getting saturation coverage I don't know either...

PM

https://www.ft.com...-b60a-de4532d5ea35

11:03 am
PM

Wells Fargo has been hit by the US consumer finance watchdog’s largest fine to date after regulators found staff racing to meet sales targets secretly opened millions of accounts without customers’ knowledge.

Thousands of employees at the world’s most valuable bank may have opened more than 2m deposit and credit card accounts across the country without customers’ permission, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) said on Thursday. Wells Fargo will pay $185m in fines as well as restitution.

About 5,300 Wells Fargo workers have lost their jobs as a result of the misconduct since 2011, the regulator said. Staff faked email addresses to create accounts and even went as far as to create PIN numbers for customers without telling them.

PM

It beggars belief

PM

Press release is here: http://www.consume...thorized-accounts/

11:04 am
PM

Full consent order is here: http://files.consu...FBconsentorder.pdf

BE

It does beggar belief, though one can see how it got here.

BE

Banks aggressively cross sell. That's how we got PPI, and it's why I've a current account I never use that's attached to my mortgage.

11:05 am
BE

So Wells Fargo opened 1.5M deposit accounts (!) and 565,000 credit card accounts (!!!) without proper authorisation.

PM

And shifted customers money around to suit

BE

That's the worst bit! That's the real clincher here.

11:06 am
PM

And charged em for the priviledge

BE

Clearly, they were at the far end of the spectrum here.

BE

Note the refunds are only $2.6m in customer fees though.

11:06 am
BE

Most of the accounts were opened just so managers could hit targets.

BE

Which banks to that? Well, all of them.

BE

Do they all get proper authorisation? Maybe. Maybe not.

11:08 am
BE

I'm not defending Wells Fargo here. Clearly, there was an institutional level of wrongdoing being promoted somewhere in the chain.

BE

Though it strikes me it's just the most egregious example of widespread industry practice.

PM

Well, i though the average person would just think: "Call the police!"

Oh and there's this

PM

PM

PM

Anyway

PM

Let

11:10 am

Let's move on

undefined

Blimey, it's a bit Friday

BE

FTSE off 0.3%, 17 points.

BE

Not much in terms of a trend to it all.

11:12 am
BE

So I guess we can just bump through the movers individually.

Wetherspoon numbers

J D Wetherspoon PLC (JDW:LSE): Last: 969.00, up 45 (+4.87%), High: 979.50, Low: 939.50, Volume: 194.75k
BE

(@Flaneur: we try to meet that requirement.)

PM

Finals here: http://www.investe...1609090700074051J/

The share price reflects relief i guess

Yeah, though in line is better than Greene King, which says it's slowed in recent weeks.

11:14 am
Greene King PLC (GNK:LSE): Last: 808.50, down 31.5 (-3.75%), High: 825.00, Low: 794.00, Volume: 1.37m
BE

That, I think, shows what kind of pessimism was already priced into the sector.

PM

Tim Martin's really gone off on one, of course

11:15 am
BE

Of course.

BE

Brexit, I assume.

PM

"Just as the combined intellectual weight of the 'good and great' could not see through the flaws in the euro, they have, with honourable exceptions, been unable to see that the principle flaw of the EU - an absence of democracy - will almost certainly lead to further economic and political chaos, and to more dire consequences for those who are subject to EU decisions. The overwhelming economic evidence is that successful countries are democracies -

Mr Johnson and like-minded economists really do need to stick that point in their pipes and smoke it. For all their faults, democracies produce the greatest level of prosperity and freedom. As in the case of the euro, the general public has a much better perception about this overriding factor than the consensus of intellectual opinion. I have written an article on this general subject for Wetherspoon News, which is attached at the end of this statement (appendix 1).

11:16 am
PM

"Now that the gloomy economic forecasts for the immediate aftermath of the referendum have been proven to be false, 'Scare Story 2' is that failure to agree on trade deal with the EU will have devastating consequences. This was articulated by fund manager Nicola Horlick this week, who told Radio 4 listeners that leaving the Single Market would relegate the UK from the 5th-biggest economy in the world to the 8th or 9th. In contrast, Wetherspoon's experience indicates that reaching formal trade deals with reluctant counterparties is impossible - and it is unwise to try.

PM

Is Nicola Horlick still managing funds?

PM

I thought she'd gone into film finance or something

11:16 am
PM

Or had a restaurant in Barnes

PM

Post Madoff

BE

(@Dust: no need whatsoever for a statement unless talks are active. Morgan Stanley's house broker anyway. And as we said at length yesterday, it looked a funny sort of story.)

11:17 am
PM

Martin goes on and on and on

PM

Can't be bothered to quote more

BE

Yeah, please don't. It's one of these companies you need to look at independent to its founder.

11:18 am
PM

What and not focus on the scars it's left across British towns the length and breadth of the country?

BE

The argument here is that if there weren't Wetherspoons we'd still have grand bank headquarters, variety theatres and suchlike filling our town centres?

BE

I'm not entirely sold on that. I'd rather a Wetherspoons than a load of flats to be sold to Chinese investors off plan in a hotel suite in Chengdu.

11:20 am
BE

Though I agree it's a marginal call.

BE

Anyway.

BE

Here are the bullet points on Wetherspoon.

11:21 am
BE

Via Barclays.

BE

· PBT ex-property gains £75.3m, vs Bloomberg consensus £72.7m and Barclays £69.6m. This is 4% down on last year on an underlying basis. Repairs and maintenance is £54.9m, up on the prior year but slightly lower as a % of sales (3.4% vs. 3.5% for FY15).

· Free Cash Flow £90.5m, vs our expectation of £81.3m. This is below FY15, but largely due to an extremely large working capital inflow in FY15 which looked ‘above average’ vs a small outflow in FY16.

· EPS was +4% to 48.3p vs consensus 45.5p and Barclays 43p.

· Operating margins for FY16 were 6.9% (vs 6.8% expected from the pre-close statement), and this has trended upwards after the implementation of price increases towards the back end of the financial year.

· Current trading: Sales growth in the new financial year is strong, at +4.1% (number of weeks not disclosed, but JDW is a July year end, so c6 weeks seems likely). We also not that this does not say LFL sales, merely “sales”. Hence, it is unclear what LFL sales are trending at. They could be higher, given that JDW closed 41 sites in FY16 vs 16 opened.

· Despite this slight unknown, this seems to be an improvement versus the FY16 LFLs of 3.4%, but close to the pre-close LFL run-rate of 4.0%. 6 week LFL comps from last year were relatively weak at +1.4%.

· The outlook says “we currently anticipate a slightly improved trading outcome for the current financial year, compared with our expectations at the pre-close stage”. The shares have rerated since the strong pre-close statement, with the share price up 34% over the past 2 months.

· Addressing the potential issue of the Chairman’s stake moving over 30% if buybacks continue (which we would expect): “Over the last 10 years, my shareholding has increased from 21.2% to 29.5%, as a result of the company's share 'buybacks'. The company is considering seeking a rule 9 'whitewash', under the UK City Code on Takeovers and Mergers, allowing further buybacks.”

· The statement is well worth a read as usual, given the Chairman’s strong opinions on Brexit, with section headings including “Superiority” and “Groupthink”.

· Valuation (Dec 17): PE 19.9x, EV/EBITDA 9.4x, FCF yield (pre expansionary capex) 7.9% and a dividend yield of 1.5% (albeit note Barclays forecasts are below Bloomberg consensus).

BE

And those on Greene King, again via Barclays.

11:21 am
BE

· IMS reveals a slowdown in trading in the past 10 weeks. Retail (managed) LFL sales in the 18 weeks to 4th September grew by 1.7%, compared with 2.8% after the first 8 weeks (this period was boosted by the European Football Championships).

· Assuming equal weighting, this implies only 0.8% growth in the last 10 weeks, but given the ex-Euro LFL was unknown the underlying trading trends are probably little changed. Our Barclaycard data released on Tuesday had pointed to robust pub trading in August on the back of decent weather for the month, so we are a little surprised that this statement isn’t stronger.

· That said, our forecast for Retail LFLs in FY17 is 1.8%. Comps for Greene King for the same 10 weeks of last year were robust at c1.9%, though the consolidated LFLs (inc Spirit) will have been dragged down by LFLs of 0.8% within the Spirit Retail estate. Spirit and Greene King are now reported on a combined basis vs separately in the prior year.

· Pub Partners (tenanted) LFLs were strong at +4.5% after 16 weeks versus 2% in the comparable period. The statement also mentions the uncertainty surrounding the result of the UK Referendum and the ensuing softening of economic indicators and leisure spending, but states that the company “has a track record of success in challenging trading environments”.

· Overall, management “remain confident of delivering another year of strategic and financial progress”. Greene King is among our favoured pub stocks due to its relatively undemanding valuation, freehold backing, and strong track record of dividend growth.

· Valuation: Dec-17 PE 10.6x, EV/EBITDA 8.8x, FCF yield 8.3% (pre expansionary capex) and 4.3% dividend yield.

BE

So -- drink in the latter and invest in the former. That seems to be the argument.

undefined
11:22 am
BE

Back into the FTSE, and to the fallers.

BE

Ashtead leading us down, post the results yesterday.

BE

And the resultant big rally.

11:23 am
Ashtead Group PLC (AHT:LSE): Last: 1,242, down 48 (-3.72%), High: 1,278, Low: 1,241, Volume: 780.88k
BE

Couple of downgrades around, such as Berenberg, saying the numbers weren't nearly as good as they looked.

BE

Strong start to the year: Ashtead has reported a strong Q1 2017 that
showed rental revenue up 12% and EBITA up 4% (both on a constant
currency basis). On the conference call the CEO was optimistic regarding
the outlook and believes Ashtead is likely to enjoy another 4-5 years of
“moderate” cyclical growth. Capital expenditure ytd of £328m is at the
upper end of management’s expectations at this stage of the year and
supports management’s confident outlook. While the year has started well,
we are concerned about the recent slowdown in US non-residential
construction expenditure which has coincided with a slowdown in
Sunbelt’s (Ashtead’s US business, 92% of EBITA) same store growth, and
hence we downgrade to Hold.

11:24 am
BE

● US non-residential cycle slows: US non-residential construction
expenditure growth, to which Sunbelt is highly exposed, has slowed
sharply over the past few months. Following strong growth in 2014 (9%),
2015 (7%) and Q1 2016 (10%) the growth has slowed to 3% in Q2 and was
flat in July. This has corresponded with a slowdown in Sunbelt’s same
store sales growth which grew only c8% in Q1 2017 (adjusted for billing
days), down from 11% in Q4 2016.

BE

● EBITA margins stall: Ashtead’s group EBITA margin in Q1 2017 stalled,
increasing only 10bp to 29.2%. This is driven by a combination of factors
which include weak yield growth (-1% at Sunbelt in Q1) and as a greater
portion of growth is coming from greenfield sites which initially generate
lower margins and returns (greenfields in their first year generated an
EBITA margin of 28% in FY 2016 versus the division on 31%). We have
lowered our EBITA margin assumptions for the group to reflect this and to
incorporate a lower EBITA contribution from sales of second-hand
equipment.

BE

● Valuation looks fair: We lower our EPS by between 5% and 7% in FY 2017-
19E driven largely by our lower EBITA margin assumptions and a higher
interest cost. Ashtead has re-rated by c50% over the past six months and
now trades on December 2017 P/E of 12.4x, and EV/EBITA of 9.7x. This is
broadly in line with the wider rental equipment sector and appears fair in
our view given the current deterioration in the US non-residential
construction cycle. Our revised EPS numbers are now broadly in line with
Bloomberg consensus. We retain our price target of 1,200p and, given the
strong recent share price performance, now downgrade our
recommendation to Hold.

BE

The Shirebook tour seems to have been fascinating, for those invited (NFI), and it seems that Ashley's getting a better press just by making himself more available.

11:29 am
BE

An odd thing about recent events -- from the Parliamentary hearing to the video of him unloading £1000 in £50s and a burner phone into the security tray -- is that they've humanised him a bit.

BE

And perhaps he'll warm to the attention. I'll take 3-1 on him appearing on Have I Got News For You before the end of 2017.

BE

Anyway, here's Peel Hunt.

11:31 am
BE

As a rule, we do not like double up/downgrades, but when a
company is set to change the way it comes to market quite so
dramatically, we can’t help but feel Damascene. Our Sell case
never surrounded working practices or corporate governance
(though both are obviously crucial), it was more to do with the
paucity of quality third-party branded product in stores. SPD
was doubtless in “mea culpa” mood at the Open Day but the
rhetoric regarding its retail strategy and tactics (“pile it high, sell
it cheap just doesn’t work now” and “we have to be more
respectful of other people’s brand equity”), and the possible pace
of change (12 key location stores a year: previously two) was
extremely encouraging. The forecasts have not quite stopped
falling yet (pre-opening costs will hold the EBITDA bounce
back until 2019) but the difference here is that we can now see
the bottom (19p of EPS?). If Sports Direct can genuinely move
the dial with suppliers, then it is pretty easy to find the valuation
interesting. BUY from SELL.

BE

Jonathan Pritchard is the analyst here.

BE

Not all about Shirebrook and the board. Working practices must improve and
the press/unions/shareholders will ensure promises are kept. We have always
been more concerned about the deterioration in third-party product here. This
was a function, we thought, of poor store standards. We felt management was in
denial, but the Open Day helped change our thinking on strategy and tactics.

11:32 am
BE

(An argument we've made repeatedly here, I think.)

BE

“Long jump to pole vault”. Sports Direct has been built on a no frills value
approach. It is becoming increasingly clear that it is no longer appropriate, either
for suppliers, or for customers, and SPD’s direction of travel is changing to reflect
that. The product that SPD is receiving is not good enough, and the only way to
get back in suppliers’ good books is to show that it can merchandise third-party
product well and to respect brand equity. More of the same (in any part of SPD)
will not work and whilst 12 big stores a year will not come cheap (and actually
drive downgrades today), restoring SPD’s own brand equity is crucial here.

BE

BUY from SELL. Amongst all the panto at the Open Day, we sensed a genuine
will to change strategy. The market is pricing in further consensus downgrades
but we think our EPS numbers now reflect the nadir: recovery will take time but
we see potential for medium-term margin rebuild and thus reverse our stance.

11:32 am
BE

......... all of which sounds sensible enough to me.

PM

hmm, tend to agree (reluctantly)

undefined
11:33 am
BE

While we're in retail (of sorts)

PM

Welcome to Markets Live

BE

Such as Burberry, which is reacting rather badly to being cut from some Goldman focus list or other.

11:34 am
BE

The GS SUSTAIN. (Their capitals, not mine.)

BE

In an increasingly growth-challenged world (see our February 22 report,
Confronting the Scarcity of Growth), we continue to seek strong cash
generators with access to predictable long-term growth, and we make a
number of changes to our GS SUSTAIN Focus List. Among Industrials, we
add Acuity Brands, the largest global provider of advanced LED lighting
and control systems, and one of our highlighted beneficiaries of the
emerging Low Carbon Economy (see our July 20 report, The Low Carbon
Economy: Our Thesis in 60 Charts). In Healthcare we add Cochlear, the
innovation leader in the underpenetrated market for implantable hearing
devices, and a longstanding member of our GS SUSTAIN ANZ List. Finally,
within Information Technology, we add Facebook to the ranks of the
asset-light tech disruptors on our FL (alongside Alphabet, Amazon and
Tencent) that is able to leverage its world-leading user base and mobile
engagement to monetize long-term growth (see our April 18 report,
Defending disruption).

BE

We make selected removals from our Focus List where our view of longterm
access to growth, competitive positioning or business risk has
diminished: Biogen, BorgWarner, Burberry, Commonwealth Bank of
Australia, Centrica, Liberty Global, Monsanto, Novatek and W.W. Grainger.
We also remove two companies: (1) LinkedIn has entered into a definitive
agreement to be acquired and for whom business fundamentals are no
longer the primary determinant of the share price as a result, and (2) ARM
Holdings has been acquired.

11:36 am
PM

Looks to be a pretty eclectic basket of stocks

BE

Yeah, and I do wonder if fund managers go into client meetings preparing to say that they've reweighted their basket in favour of asset-light tech disruptors.

BE

I'd end that meeting pretty damn quick.

11:37 am
BE

Here's the Burberry blurb.

BE

Burberry: Over the last two years (FY14-16), Burberry has seen weaker than expected
financial performance with EPS down 2% and group CROCI down 407bp to 17.7%. The key drivers of this deterioration have been subdued sales growth and increasing costs
associated with the company’s strategic investments, including omni-channel. We are
concerned that these headwinds continue, and note that our analyst now expects EPS
CAGR of 6% over FY16-21E with CROCI falling 206bp over this period. The more subdued outlook and concerns regarding the company’s ability to regain prior levels of profitability lead us to remove the company from the GS SUSTAIN Focus List.

undefined
11:38 am
BE

There's also a big retail piece out from Exane, but I haven't had time to go through it all.

BE

Mostly downgrades. Kingfisher, Inchcape, Sports Direct ......

BE

And cautious on Supergroup.

11:39 am
BE

Actually, it's three individual notes. Three! But because Exane are nice people they've sent a very tight summary of each.

BE

(1) The calm before the perfect storm

BE

Oblivious to upcoming headwinds, the UK consumer has continued to spend whilst they have cash. This won't last, the era of positive sector LFL is over
 Looking for flat LFL in 2017, we cut UK sector earnings by 8%. Having largely recovered its post-Brexit fall, the equity market looks too sanguine on prospects for retailers
Change in category spend is likely to be less pronounced than before; we expect clothing to be less resilient and DIY and Electrical declines to be less pronounced
 With share prices within reach of target prices, this drives recommendation cuts on Kingfisher (to =) and weighs on Inchcape (to =)
We also step away from troubled Signet (to =) and can’t justify valuation on Sports Direct (to -), despite the risk of “selling the kitchen sink”
 Trends in Europe are more stable, but after a strong recovery, we again pause for breath on highly valued Inditex (to =)
* There is more on recommendation changes at the bottom of this email if of interest

11:40 am
BE

(2) Clothing Wars Episode 2: A New Hope

BE

The second in our series looking at the changing world of clothing retail, as we look at online in a new way
 Changes go well beyond much-quoted headline channel shares. Sources of influence, places to browse, and channels to purchase are all undergoing profound changes.
This might sound like an arbitrary difference – it is anything but
 For mass-market retailers this turns well-established barriers to entry into hard-to-break barriers to success
For nimble brands this offers new exciting global opportunities
 BUT most importantly, this opens up opportunities for newcomers to reinvent the clothing retail model
Boohoo are leading the charge, and by virtue of their background have a global head start
 This disruptive model makes fast fashion even faster and makes a winning model even better
Valued as an online retailer it may not be to everyone’s liking, but understanding this development is crucial for anyone interested in any clothing retailer
 We initiate on Boohoo, a top pick, target price 120p. In outer years are revenue forecasts are double-digit ahead of consensus

Boohoo.Com PLC (BOO:LSE): Last: 91.25, up 0.75 (+0.83%), High: 92.00, Low: 90.25, Volume: 1.91m
11:40 am
BE

(3) Battle of the brands

BE

In the context of developments which play to the positioning of nimble brands…we initiate on Ted Baker and Supergroup
 Many brands offer the world, but few stand the test of time
An in-depth review of the rise, and all-too-often fall of global brands has led us to develop a framework to identify winners and avoid losers
 Ted Baker sits firmly as one of the former: well distributed with growing desirability; steady global success looks well underpinned and is worth paying for
There are more questions to be asked over Supergroup: association to branding, deteriorating returns and slowing traction in the UK are worrisome signs…the strategy here raises some eyebrows as well…but international gives plenty to go for, so we wouldn’t be negative…nonetheless the investment case is certainly more balanced
 We initiate on Ted Baker, another top pick, target price 3500p
* We initiate on Supergroup, neutral, target price 1650p

SuperGroup PLC (SGP:LSE): Last: 1,505, down 24 (-1.57%), High: 1,522, Low: 1,500, Volume: 24.61k
11:41 am
Ted Baker PLC (TED:LSE): Last: 2,733, down 23 (-0.83%), High: 2,815, Low: 2,717, Volume: 6.27k
Kingfisher PLC (KGF:LSE): Last: 368.05, down 6.45 (-1.72%), High: 370.60, Low: 367.50, Volume: 4.67m
BE

11:42 am
undefined
PM

Mentioning earlier about asset light tech disruptors

BE

Yes! Asset light tech disruptors!

11:43 am
PM

Reminds me that Morgan Stanley have some massive tome out on digital seemingly fixing the productivity issue

PM

We live in a paradoxical world - there are visible technological changes all around us yet productivity growth has stalled. We see scope for digitalization to re-accelerate productivity growth. We identify investment opportunities in the top global scaling disruptors and digitalization enablers.

PM

There is an apparent contradiction between very visible technological changes in our day-to-day lives and a noticeable downshift in measured productivity growth. Global growth has been stagnating for the past 10 years with headwinds from demographics and lower productivity growth due to the slowdown in the diffusion of new technologies. There is currently lots of hope around the Fourth Industrial Revolution and full Artificial Intelligence, which in a bull case could potentially lead to decades of global GDP growth above 3% (using 1945-2005 US GDP growth as a guide). But such a quantum leap compared to today's technologies would require: 1) a new source of energy, which does not emit CO2, is cost competitive vs oil and with vast storage; and 2) a new source of computational power beyond Moore’s Law.

11:43 am
PM

But we are still in the tail of the Third Industrial or Digital Revolution where investment in digitalization could drive significant productivity gains. Our analysis suggests that the US economy is only 27% digitalized and that there are lots inefficiencies to be unlocked, which could increase the level of digitalization to 43% in the next 5-10 years. The speed at which this transformation occurs will depend on the level of investments in the Internet of Things, Big Data, and data driven business process optimization.

PM

Our Digitalization Index highlights pockets of inefficiencies that could be unlocked today. From a bottom-up perspective, Pharma/Healthcare, Autos and Capital Goods/Manufacturing are amongst the least digitalized sectors. Our in-depth sector analysis in this report reveals that over the next decade of digitalization, there could be five more drugs approved by the FDA every year (compared to 28 today), that US manufacturing output could increase by up to 50% to $8.7trn, and that better use of data would allow more efficient transportation representing up to $4trn of utility TAM through shared mobility.

PM

Digitalization Index, hmm

11:43 am
PM

Global top picks: Scaling disruptors include Google, Amazon, Apple, Priceline Booking.com, Alibaba, Baidu, Facebook, Netflix, Tencent. A full list of 46 disruption enablers is set out in Exhibit 41.

PM

I will try and get the Digitalization Index

PM

11:44 am
PM

Oh and hyou hsould have this

PM

Sorry for typing

PM

You know what i meant to say

11:45 am
PM

PM

Make of that what you will

PM

Transitioning from one revolution to another does not make the previous one redundant. We still use cotton fabrics, trains, cars, and banks, and we will still use phones. The companies that produce these goods and services do survive and continue to innovate; they mature and continue pushing the cost curve, but they do not drive the next quantum leap innovations. That said, transitioning to the next industrial revolution has always required a quantum leap in innovation, requiring significant amounts of time and money to blossom. It took nearly 40 years of R&D for the internal combustion engine to become a viable option versus the steam engine and while the transistor was invented at the Bell Labs in 1948 the Personal Computer only reached office desks in 1981.

The three industrial revolutions have driven GDP growth and created new companies adding significant value to global market capitalization. The tail of the Third Industrial Revolution is unlikely to add significantly to market capitalization; however, should corporates invest enough in Big Data and the Internet of Things, it could still provide a much needed boost to productivity growth and stalled GDP. The Fourth Industrial Revolution - when it comes - will add to both.

11:46 am
PM

Yeah, I'll usual place it

BE

Right, okay. That's fascinating. But should I buy or sell my Webvan shares? I'm not clear.

undefined
11:47 am
PM

I see Alain Bokobza of SocGen is on his travels again

PM

You may remember we featured some of his letters from the Far east last year

PM

Well, now he's in Russia

11:48 am
PM

Send a Postcard from Moscow

PM

No, it was not snowing. The weather in this season can be wonderful (15-20°C during the day), with beautiful light playing on the fine facades of Russia's magnificent capital. In between client meetings with both large corporates and asset managers, I had a chat with our local Head of Research, Yuri Tulinov, and our Russian Economist, Evgeny Koshelev. We enjoyed a lively discussion about a wide range of subjects. Having arrived relatively bullish on Russian assets, I returned to Paris super bullish, and even more so than Yuri or Evgeny.

PM

In flashbacks to the James Bond movie ‘From Russia with Love', I discovered that when you ask for a Coke they still serve you a Pepsi, and also that none of my high-level contacts expect US sanctions on Russia to be removed anytime soon. That said, I got the impression that Russia could see positive side effects should Donald Trump win the US presidency (so buy RUB/sell MXN if you gear up for a Trump victory). On the other hand, Hillary Clinton, should she win in November, is seen remaining in “super tough” mode like Barack Obama.

11:49 am
PM

Sanctions have hit Russia hard, but there is a silver lining, i.e. a flat trend in Russian corporate debt, as foreign banks are not allowed to lend to large Russian corporates. Meanwhile, corporate debt has soared in the vast majority of emerging markets, from Brazil to China, triggering structural, if not systemic, risk. Buoyant domestic financial markets in Russia should allow for much better asset liability management, with large imbalances in fixed/floating rates and currency mismatch between revenues and debt. This should create room for the risk premium to fall in a country where bank liquidity is sharply improving and the current account remains positive at 3% of GDP.

PM

To be frank, I'd only trust a piece of investment research like this if it was written after the author had left the country

PM

Russia's scary

11:50 am
PM

Please remind me to practice pronouncing “Evgeny” properly, as I plan to return to Russia.

Landing in Paris, the Aeroflot flight attendant announced that it was 23°C outside, adding "above zero".

Modeling the B2C membership on a subscriber basis combined with a detailed
analysis of the cost per case drives upside: We model paid retention reaching
82% (in line with implied 2H 2016) versus 81% in 2016, while the market is pricing
in 75%. A 1% improvement in retention is worth 10p per share, but stabilisation of
B2C membership improves LT returns and should drive a rerating. Our 3-4.5%/1-
6% roadside assistance revenue/EBITDA growth 2017-19e compares to 3% and -
1/+4% before. Our EBITDA estimates are now 2-9% above 2017-19 consensus.

offer upside: Discussions with our insurance research team and the company

Cash flow, returns and debt levels should all improve from fiscal 2018e:

from 29/25% in 2017e to 32/28% in 2018e).
A material increase in IAS 19 pension deficit at 1H + the triennial review is due:

19 impacts EV multiples, but not covenant ratios or financing prospects.
PT increased to 360p, FCF yield looks attractive: Improving B2C performance,
combined with our analysis of its motor insurance business drives a more
optimistic view of cash flow progression and LT growth. Our LT growth rate to
3% from 2.5% previously, more than offsets the IAS 19 deficit increase and our PT
increases to 360p. Its FCF yield of 5/12/16% in 2017/18/19e looks attractive.
Key risks: A material increase in the 1H IAS 19 pension deficit. Execution in
insurance. B2C customer retention initiatives fail.

BE

Understanding risks presents opportunities
Positioning for a recovery in oil prices: Investors often look to the E&P sector as a way to play a recovery in the oil price, and we think some companies are smarter ways to play a recovery than others from a risk/reward perspective. When thinking of how to position for a recovery in oil prices, we analyse E&Ps through a five part framework involving: i) balancing oil price leverage with funding risk; ii) ability to refinance, iii) project execution risk, iv) exploration upside and v) M&A.

BE

Change of analysts, this. Justin Teo's now lead.

BE

Cairn Energy (upgrade to Outperform from Neutral, TP 255p from 215p) is our top pick. It is on the verge of returning to production in 2017, re-establishing itself as a full-cycle E&P company that funds future exploration from organic cash flows. It also has exposure to an exciting oil discovery in Senegal, where the current ~500mmbbl resource has the potential to grow in size towards the large 2.74bn oil in place estimate.

11:55 am
BE

Ophir Energy (downgrade to Underperform from Neutral, TP 70p from 95p) has a business model that relies heavily on divestments for funding, but it is currently difficult to sell assets, making it hard for us to see a farm-in partner entering Fortuna FLNG at a decent price. Even if sanctioned, Fortuna carries significant execution risk, in our view.

BE

Tullow Oil's (downgrade to Neutral, from Outperform, TP 240p from 300p) ability to deleverage is largely linked to whether it can divest a stake in Uganda, and while we think the market is overly pessimistic about its ability to sell-down given Total's interest in driving the project forward, there is limited upside, given the share price implies oil prices of ~$68/bbl.

BE

Other stock calls: Lundin Petroleum (Underperform, TP Skr135 from SKr130) is a well run company with quality assets, but we struggle on valuation grounds as it is priced for perfect execution, and trades at a premium to our NAV. We find it difficult to see much upside potential in Genel Energy (upgrade to Neutral from Underperform, TP 100p from 85p), given the reservoir uncertainties surrounding Taq Taq, although regular monthly payments by the KRG are encouraging. We upgrade Premier Oil to Neutral, from Underperform (TP unchanged at 70p), given a potential near-term boost from completion of debt refinancing.

PM

Fraud by abuse of position (Section 4)
The defendant:

occupies a position in which he was expected to safeguard, or not to act against, the financial interests of another person
abused that position
dishonestly
intending by that abuse to make a gain/cause a loss
The abuse may consist of an omission rather than an act.

Like the other two Section 1 offences, Section 4 is entirely offender focused. It is complete once the Defendant carries out the act that is the abuse of his position. It is immaterial whether or not he is successful in his enterprise and whether or not any gain or loss is actually made.

As with all the Section 1 offences, though there need be no consequences to the offending, the existence and extent of those consequences will be very material to sentence, compensation and confiscation. It will still therefore be necessary to gather that evidence. In many instances it is the fact of the gain or loss that will prove the Defendant's dishonesty beyond reasonable doubt.
